description: From Middle English enheriten, from Old French enheriter, from Late Latin inhereditare (“make heir”). Displaced native Old English ierfan.

verbs.description: inherit (third-person singular simple present inherits, present participle inheriting, simple past and past participle inherited)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To take possession of as a right (especially in Biblical translations).
examples: Your descendants will inherit the earth.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To receive (property, a title, etc.), by legal succession or bequest after the previous owner's death.
examples: After Grandad died, I inherited the house.

entries.meaning: (transitive, biology) To receive a characteristic from one's ancestors by genetic transmission.
examples: Let's hope the baby inherits his mother's looks and his father's intelligence.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To derive from people or conditions previously in force.
examples: This country has inherited an invidious class culture.
Lucky old Daniel – his grandfather died rich, and he's inherited.

entries.meaning: (computing, programming, transitive) To derive (existing functionality) from a superclass.
examples: ModalWindow inherits all the properties and methods of Window.

entries.meaning: (computing, programming, transitive) To derive a new class from (a superclass).
(transitive, obsolete) To put in possession of.
